intro: Hieracium flagellare subsp. subsarmentosum, commonly known as the creeping hawkweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its hairy, leafy stems and yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in moist meadows, woodlands, and along stream banks. Its subspecies subsarmentosum is distinguished by its creeping growth habit and shorter, more compact stems. It plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a host plant for certain insect species.
